claim: The Lindbergh kidnapping case was solved, although alternative theories still exist.

supporting.text: Bruno Hauptmann was convicted and executed for the Lindbergh kidnapping, providing a legal resolution to the case.

attacks.text: Bruno Hauptmann was convicted and executed for the Lindbergh kidnapping, providing a legal resolution to the case.
Hauptmann maintained his innocence until his execution, and some evidence suggests he may have been framed or coerced.
Forensic analysis and witness testimony at the time strongly supported Hauptmann's guilt, making claims of framing speculative.
The trial was highly sensationalized, potentially influencing the jury and leading to a miscarriage of justice.
Legal scholars note that despite media attention, the trial followed standard judicial procedures and evidence was thoroughly examined.

supporting.text: Forensic evidence, including the ransom money found in Hauptmann's possession, directly linked him to the crime.

attacks.text: Forensic evidence, including the ransom money found in Hauptmann's possession, directly linked him to the crime.
The ransom money could have been planted or Hauptmann could have obtained it unknowingly from the real kidnapper.
No credible evidence supports the claim that the ransom money was planted, and Hauptmann's own testimony was inconsistent.
Other forensic evidence, such as the ladder used in the kidnapping, did not conclusively match Hauptmann's tools or materials.
Expert testimony at the trial confirmed that the wood and tool marks on the ladder were consistent with Hauptmann's workshop.

supporting.text: Alternative theories lack substantial evidence to overturn the official conclusion of Hauptmann's guilt.

attacks.text: Alternative theories lack substantial evidence to overturn the official conclusion of Hauptmann's guilt.
Some alternative theories suggest Hauptmann was framed, pointing to inconsistencies in the prosecution's evidence.
Forensic experts have re-examined the evidence and found no conclusive proof that Hauptmann was framed.
Eyewitness testimony in the case was unreliable, casting doubt on the official conclusion.
Modern forensic techniques have corroborated key aspects of the original investigation.

supporting.text: The Lindbergh kidnapping case remains officially closed by law enforcement, indicating it was solved.

attacks.text: The Lindbergh kidnapping case remains officially closed by law enforcement, indicating it was solved.
Official closure does not necessarily mean the case was fully or correctly solved, as seen in other historical cases where authorities prematurely closed investigations.
Authorities often close cases due to resource constraints or political pressure, not because all questions are answered.
Alternative theories persist among credible researchers, suggesting unresolved inconsistencies in the official narrative.
Many alternative theories lack concrete evidence and rely on speculation, making them less credible than the official conclusion.

supporting.text: Historical consensus among legal and criminological experts supports the view that Hauptmann was the perpetrator.

attacks.text: Historical consensus among legal and criminological experts supports the view that Hauptmann was the perpetrator.
Some forensic experts argue that the evidence against Hauptmann was circumstantial and could have been planted or misinterpreted.
The wood analysis linking Hauptmann to the ladder was later criticized for lacking scientific rigor and reproducibility.
Alternative theories suggest organized crime involvement, which was not thoroughly investigated due to public pressure for a quick resolution.
Historical records show that law enforcement at the time dismissed alternative leads prematurely, focusing solely on Hauptmann.

supporting.text: The absence of credible alternative suspects undermines alternative theories about the kidnapping.

attacks.text: The absence of credible alternative suspects undermines alternative theories about the kidnapping.
The investigation was flawed, potentially overlooking credible suspects due to tunnel vision on Hauptmann.
Historical reviews and modern forensic analysis have not uncovered overlooked suspects, supporting the original conclusion.
Alternative theories often rely on circumstantial evidence, which lacks the credibility to challenge the official narrative.
Some alternative theories are supported by credible witnesses or documentation that was dismissed prematurely.
